In his blog post today, Jared Bernstein, provides a counter to your arguments. In a society whose government, laws, economy, and politics are dictated to by whomever holds the most wealth, effort alone, on the part of 99% of the population, will yield nothing. That is the nature and effect of an oligarchy.

"I’ve been arguing against these positions for decades, backed by considerable empirical evidence showing that moderate changes to tax rates, minimum wages, union density, the safety net, regulatory oversight and so on trigger nothing like the disasters their opponents claim and can yield important benefits (which is not to say there are no “negative impacts” at all). And please don't forget big insurance. Very little has been done to tame that dragon. People are still paying exorbitant amounts to be insured and that graft goes straight into the pockets of the likes of Blue Cross, Cigna and Aetna who administrate poorly and drive up fees while taking maximum profits.

Although it is true, as you say, that Big Medical Device and Big Pharma sate their voracious appetites at the healthcare table, a seismic change is occurring in healthcare delivery that will equip providers with the tools needed to reduce these costs. Patient centered care, digital healthcare information in the aggregate and on demand, hospital consolidation and the formulation of integrated delivery networks, hospital mergers with insurance companies to form accountable care models, have all positioned healthcare providers to treat patients at the right place and time at the most appropriate cost.

Just the collection of patient outcome data in the aggregate compiled using health information exchanges will finally provide the phase IV, post marketing study that so few drug companies bother with. Think of Vioxx, an anti inflammatory drug with fatal cardiac side effects that went undetected during the phase III clinical trial. Avoiding these negative outcomes will save lives and money. The list goes on. There is reason to be optimistic.

I am a supporter of the ACA and better yet, a single payer system. But I have a sincere question for the many people who criticize 'obscene' pharmaceutical industry profits. Are you proposing that somehow the profits of publicly traded pharmaceutical companies be capped?  Should the pharmaceutical industry be nationalized and staffed with government employees? Because without a profit motive, what would drive the development of new drugs? Is it not the prospect of making profits what is behind the years of research, clinical trials, regulatory compliance, and investment of tens or hundreds of millions of dollars necessary to develop new pharmaceuticals? As we speak, pharmaceutical companies are spending huge amounts of money, and have been doing so for decades, to develop treatments for such vexing diseases as cancer, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes. It would be beneficial to create incentives for them to research less common diseases. But beyond that, what would be better than a pharmaceutical industry motivated by profit?

In addition to taking a big bite out of the uninsured population in the US, subsidized by the wealthiest, the Affordable Care Act has also changed the rules for private insurance in a way that is irreversible. GOP politicians know they can never propose changes to the law that allow insurance companies to deny or cancel coverage or unfairly discriminate against the less healthy, much as they can never repeal Social Security or Medicare.

But we still have a huge problem with health care in the US that eats 18% of our GDP, now surpassing what we spend on housing, the next largest category. And it's far more than we spend on food, education, defense, transportation and anything else. Its double the average spent by all other developed countries.

One half of that problem is the US health care and pharmaceutical business, whose profit demands know no bounds. While many doctors and nurses try to provide the best and most responsible care, they are overwhelmed by a avaricious and predatory system. This can only be curbed by the collective and forceful efforts of the largest payers in the system, big employers and public insurance plans. Big Pharma profits in particular are obscene.

The second half of the problem is the general health status of the US population. We have to stop being victims of the bad food industry, at home, in schools and at work. We have to become more active. And we have to stop looking for a pill for every symptom.

It could happen.

Like a Supreme Court justice once said about pornography "I know it when I see it".

I know inequality when I see it because I've been around long enough to have seen the way things used to be a few decades ago. There weren't anything like as many homeless as now. Food pantries were rare, if not unheard of. I remember public infrastructure actually worked and was taken care of, because there was a large and more or less prosperous middle class to pay taxes and because the people at the top were less grudging about the taxes they paid.

From the inside of three different Fortune 500 companies, I saw the degradation of corporate culture. Corporations used to understand that they had mutual interests with four major constituencies: their shareholders, their customers, their employees and their communities. I saw loyalty to the last three go out of the window, while the execs, focused on only the stock price, saw to it that they enriched themselves. Not coincidentally, of the three corporations I worked for, one no longer exists and the other two are shadows of their former selves. Out of that "creative destruction", most employees saw their incomes downgraded and retirees saw a lifetime of accrued benefits undermined.

And one thing you didn't mention was Social Security. It the "cap" is eliminated and the rich that pay into it for all their taxable earnings the Social Security problem disappears. But then again the rich may decide to offshore themselves like all the jobs they have taken from the United States.
Are you claiming the right to say how much money a rich man "needs", and to tell us how much money you "deserve".  Really?

The obvious reasons for having wealth is to live with more control over one's life, influence over other people's lives, to have more leisure time, and to have more access to creature comforts, including health, education, housing, and transportation. Toss in indulgences for expensive wine, jewelry, golf at Pine Valley, chauffeured limo's, yachts, and box seats at sports events.

What matters is if fewer and fewer people have so much more money than they have any need for, is this hurting the rest of us, particularly those typified by solid college graduates who cannot get a job or people working 39 hour weeks at stand up jobs, with low pay and no vacation or benefits.

I was a parole agent for the California Department of Corrections for 23 years. On April 23, 2003 I completely blew out my knee running to break up a fight on the yard. I tore my ACL. PCL, lateral and medial meniscus and my patellar tendon. I had xrays, MRI's, everything. I requested surgery. They refused. They said the the damage was too severe. I eventually had surgery on my own. They finally medically retired me on August 26, 2004. For 16 months I had no income. Where were you to help me? I had to cash in my insurance policies, the savings I had set aside for my grandkids college, some precious coins that were worth alot. I ended up with nothing. It took me 10 years to see my income rise to $36,000. was making $80,000 when I was working. So where you you to help me? You're so quick to demonize Republicans but where you to pay for my oil change that was 7,000 miles past due? Where were you to help me pay for my new glasses 6 months after I got the new prescription?
I busted my butt for 23 years. I was assaulted 7 times, my family threatened and a contract put out on my life 3 years before I left. Think you could hang? Where was your benevolent spirit? I thought Democrats took care of the down and out. Yeah, it's all talk and you're a classic example. All noise, no substance. I am not rich by any means. But even with my meager existence I'd bet the farm I give more to charity than you do in 10 years. I guess your tight fisted wealth didn't trickle down to me. Thanks.

What exactly is the Liberal version of a "rational climate policy"?

Is it redistribution via Big Gubmint taxation?

Is it 1 mile thick of ice over New York and Chicago?

No, you say? Well take a look at recent geological history and tell me exactly what your "rational policy" will be doing to prevent it.

Since you asked, "rational climate policy" is neither liberal nor conservative. Rational policy seeks the accurate prices for the goods and services we consume, rather than allowing us to externalize costs onto society. For example, the measurable (in dollars) costs of burning coal, gasoline, and other fossil fuels include not just the prices we pay, but the costs created for all citizens of the planet in the forms of more particulate matter in the air (and consequent asthma attacks and other respiratory problems which create medical bills and deaths), CO2 and other gases which create global warming and climate change (and consequent costly weather events, damage to ag production and other natural resources), etc. Rational climate policy simply expects people to actually pay prices which reflect the costs they impose on society, and currently myriad goods and services are very much underpriced.

Expecting people to simply pay accurate prices for the consumption is not liberal. It's common sense.

Dr. Krugman compares the "inequality deniers" with the "climate change deniers" without putting them together: rising inequality of income and wealth creates an increasingly powerful class of people with an interest in impeding all sorts of positive social change, including rational climate policy. Rich people, especially people who are getting richer, have a strong interest in maintaining the status quo -- and they are killing us.

About 6 weeks ago, I had a TGA event.  Unlike the author, I cannot remember anything that happened during the event and only know it existed because my wife asked me a question.  The nature of my response led her to think I was kidding, but after repeated inquiries brought the same result, she suspected a stroke and suggested we ask for help.  I became belligerent but eventually agreed.  Toward the end I do recall going to my computer to retrieve a morning entry that would convince me (and her) that I was all right.  The analysis at the emergency room declared this an unusual TGA event, since it lasted about 45 minutes.  The medical puzzle, I understand, is that total memory shutdown requires both hippocampi to be deprived of blood flow, but they have separate arterial supply.  They do both drain into a single vein where blockage could provide a single cause for simultaneous malfunction.  I'm 83 years old and I understand that the probability of a repeat is practically zero.

What is always remarkable in these slice of life drug stories is that they always come some twenty or thirty years after Americans have decided it's OK to lock up minority men if they can just find the right cause. And what could be a better reason to lock them up than selling drugs? Because they were minority men, America said, "Lock them up and throw away the key," even though most of their sales were to affluent whites.

And who was the major perpetrator of this anti-drug propaganda? The news media. And I notice the author has absolutely no historical perspective here. There is not one single reference to the left who objected vociferously to these draconian drug laws and said openly that the war on drugs was a war on minority men.

For decades.

Denying inequality isn't the primary narrative, though. The conservative worldview rests on two concepts: 1) that people should "keep their money," and 2) that they earned it by working harder than others.

The fact that people who earn a lot of money are doing it by benefiting from a vast social infrastructure they didn't create gets left out of this narrative. If there's a billionaire who has paid entirely for the schooling, roads, public safety, and infrastructure his business relies on, I want to hear about it. Or one who has sent his own children to fight in Iraq or Afghanistan, for that matter. It used to be that poor people fought the wars but rich people paid for them, which was already somewhat unfair. Now rich people don't even want to do that.

There's a historical fact that few people know, but that I think Krugman would enjoy. The person who invented the earliest version of the game Monopoly reportedly did it to prove a political point. Power begets power and money begets money. Wherever the roll of the dice lands you in your first few moves sends you not only a little ahead of others, but often allows you to completely drive your opponents into the ground. It usually isn't because you're so special, either. The game tests nothing so much as chance and people's willingness to be brutal. But people still feel special when they win. Maybe that's why it's one of America's most popular games.
If there were no rich, the best thing that could be done for everyone else would be to invent them.  When you don't understand that, you're helpless.

The temptation is to put the onus on the 1% for denying how much inequality there is among the top 1% and those below them.

But the very wealthy do not waste their time do disprove any such situation even exists. The have their hired holdovers from 19th century theory's, to do their dirty work for them. There is the Hoover Institute at Stanford, the American Enterprise Institute, the Cato Institute, and the Heritage Foundation, to do their dirty work for them.

There is a lot of money catering to the very wealthy, and giving them intellectual ammunition to refute negative facts about them. So if you are very wealthy, and you believe it is un-American to be taxed at a higher rate than the lower 50% of the population, you turn to one of the think tanks, to give you reasons to take to your legislator, along with a generous helping of pecuniary support.

At the same time, these lackeys publish doctored statistics to show that such does not really exist. And the big slur, if you are for reducing it, you are labeled a Marxist. That is another propaganda attack to discredit any kind of attempt to reduce the difference.

It is not new, it has been going on for centuries, between rich and poor.
